elements.content: Two nitro functionalized Cu­(II)-MOFs exhibit high CO2 uptake with nice selectivity over other gases like H2, N2, and CH4, which is potentially important for the removal of carbon dioxide from industrial flue gas and natural gas. Here the selective CO2 adsorption by these MOFs is primarily due to the presence of suitable voids with −NO2 group functionalized pore walls in the dehydrated framework, which is unprecedented.
elements.clean_text: Two nitro functionalized Cu(II)-MOFs exhibit high CO2 uptake with nice selectivity over other gases like H2, N2, and CH4, which is potentially important for the removal of carbon dioxide from industrial flue gas and natural gas. Here the selective CO2 adsorption by these MOFs is primarily due to the presence of suitable voids with -NO2 group functionalized pore walls in the dehydrated framework, which is unprecedented.

elements.content: Challenging syntheses of nitro functionalized Cu­(II)-MOFs encapsulating −NO2 groups in the pore walls with appreciable void spaces in their dehydrated frameworks, that exhibit enhanced selective CO2 adsorption at 195 K over all other gases.
elements.clean_text: Challenging syntheses of nitro functionalized Cu(II)-MOFs encapsulating -NO2 groups in the pore walls with appreciable void spaces in their dehydrated frameworks, that exhibit enhanced selective CO2 adsorption at 195 K over all other gases.

elements.content: The selective trapping of carbon dioxide using carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) technologies has become highly connected to the endurance of civilization nowadays due to the alarming increase of CO2 concentration which may cause several environmental disorders. Presently, along with traditional CCS methods, the use of porous coordination polymers (PCPs), which are prevalently known as metal organic frameworks (MOFs), has taken enormous attention for the selective CO2 adsorption due to the presence of highly ordered pores, large surface areas, and high thermal/solution stability. To make a MOF suitable for selective CO2 sequestration, the first criterion is to have porosity of the MOF comparable to the kinetic diameter of CO2. Moreover, as the CO2 is a molecule with quadruple moment, a polar pore decorated with −NH2, −OH, −NN–, and −NC­(R)– moieties is necessary to increase the CO2-framework affinity enabling the resulting MOF for highly selective separation of CO2 from the mixtures of gases. In this context, the use of these functional group containing MOFs is exhaustively explored and it has been almost established that the amino group is the most suitable among the various functional groups as the amino functionalized MOFs show nice selectivity on CO2. The nitro group having a polar nature and the possibility for better interaction with the quadruple moment of CO2 can also be good stuff for showing such selectivity (). However, the nitro functionalized MOFs are not yet found so effective in CO2 sequestration, as it is very difficult to embed the nitro group centric toward the pore void. This is probably due to the large size of the nitro group which deflects its location from the pore wall. Moreover, the bulky nitro groups can block the pore volume which also acts negatively for their use in designing MOFs for selective CO2 separation. However, if some suitable design is made in the fabrication of the pore walls of the MOFs with nitro functionalized linkers, that can also show remarkable CO2 uptake with high selectivity.
elements.clean_text: The selective trapping of carbon dioxide using carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) technologies has become highly connected to the endurance of civilization nowadays due to the alarming increase of CO2 concentration which may cause several environmental disorders. Presently, along with traditional CCS methods, the use of porous coordination polymers (PCPs), which are prevalently known as metal organic frameworks (MOFs), has taken enormous attention for the selective CO2 adsorption due to the presence of highly ordered pores, large surface areas, and high thermal/solution stability. To make a MOF suitable for selective CO2 sequestration, the first criterion is to have porosity of the MOF comparable to the kinetic diameter of CO2. Moreover, as the CO2 is a molecule with quadruple moment, a polar pore decorated with -NH2, -OH, -NN-, and -NC(R)- moieties is necessary to increase the CO2-framework affinity enabling the resulting MOF for highly selective separation of CO2 from the mixtures of gases. In this context, the use of these functional group containing MOFs is exhaustively explored and it has been almost established that the amino group is the most suitable among the various functional groups as the amino functionalized MOFs show nice selectivity on CO2. The nitro group having a polar nature and the possibility for better interaction with the quadruple moment of CO2 can also be good stuff for showing such selectivity (). However, the nitro functionalized MOFs are not yet found so effective in CO2 sequestration, as it is very difficult to embed the nitro group centric toward the pore void. This is probably due to the large size of the nitro group which deflects its location from the pore wall. Moreover, the bulky nitro groups can block the pore volume which also acts negatively for their use in designing MOFs for selective CO2 separation. However, if some suitable design is made in the fabrication of the pore walls of the MOFs with nitro functionalized linkers, that can also show remarkable CO2 uptake with high selectivity.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">

−NH<sub>2</sub> Groups in CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption</title>

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Role of -NO2 and -NH2 Groups in CO2 Adsorption

elements.content: By the use of comparable pillar and layer linkers in mixed ligand MOF, here we have prepared a 3D porous Cu-MOF {[Cu­(azbpy)­(2-ntp)]·H2O} n (1) which shows high CO2 uptake volume due to the presence of a nitro group oriented toward the pore void. The slight increase in the length of the pillar linker produces {[Cu­(4-bpdb)­(2-ntp)]·2­(H2O)} n (2) which has a comparable pore size to that of 1, but the nitro groups are not properly facing toward the pore like 1 and that has been reflected by its comparatively lower CO2 uptake.
elements.clean_text: By the use of comparable pillar and layer linkers in mixed ligand MOF, here we have prepared a 3D porous Cu-MOF {[Cu(azbpy)(2-ntp)]⋅H2O} n  (1) which shows high CO2 uptake volume due to the presence of a nitro group oriented toward the pore void. The slight increase in the length of the pillar linker produces {[Cu(4-bpdb)(2-ntp)]⋅2(H2O)} n  (2) which has a comparable pore size to that of 1, but the nitro groups are not properly facing toward the pore like 1 and that has been reflected by its comparatively lower CO2 uptake.

elements.content: Block shaped greenish crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained at room temperature by the slow diffusion technique of aqueous solutions of Cu­(NO3)2 and the disodium salt of 2-nitroterephthalic acid, [Na2(2-ntp)], with the methanolic solution of 4,4′-azobispyridine (azbpy) and N,N′-bispyridin-4-ylmethylenehydrazine (4-bpdb) linkers for 1 and 2, respectively. Compound 1 exhibits a 3D structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cu­(II) ion, one azbpy linker, one 2-ntp2–, and one disorder lattice water molecule split into three fragments with 0.25, 0.25, and 0.5 individual occupancy. The five-coordinated Cu­(II) center with CuO3N2 coordination environment is connected by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O3 a , and O4 b ) from three 2-ntp2– and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4 c ) of two different azbpy linkers (a) exhibiting a distorted trigonal bipyramidal structure. Here each 2-ntp2– ligand bridges with three Cu­(II) centers in a bridging monodentate–bidentate fashion and exhibits a 2D sheet of [Cu­(2-ntp)] n in the crystallographic ab plane (b) through the formation of Cu3(CO2)5 trinuclear secondary building units (SBUs) (Figure S8). The 2D sheets are further connected by an azbpy ligand to form a 3D framework with water filled 1D channel along b-axis (c) with the channel dimensions of about 6.5 × 3.0 Å2 (Figure S10a). Interestingly, the nitro groups are embedded in the pore wall of the said channel, and even in the presence of bulky nitro groups, the total solvent accessible void without the lattice water molecule is pretty high, 773.5 Å3 estimated by PLATON, which is 32.7% of the total crystal volume of 2362.18 Å3. Structural analysis with TOPOS suggests that the overall framework of 1 exhibits a 3,5-c binodal net (d) with stoichiometry (3-c)­(5-c) and the corresponding Schläfli symbol is {63}­{69.8}. Compound 2 shows a 3D paddle-wheel structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cu­(II) ion, one 4-bpdb linker, one 2-ntp2–, and two lattice water molecules. The Cu­(II) center is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2 a , and O3 b ) from three different 2-ntp2– and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4 c ) from two different 4-bpdb linkers (a) and exhibits a distorted trigonal bipyramidal structure. Here each 2-ntp2– ligand bridges with three Cu­(II) centers like 1 to form a 2D sheet of [Cu­(2-ntp)] n in the bc plane (b), but the bonding of the 2-ntp2– ligand is only slightly different than that of 1. In 2 the bidentate carboxylate groups of two different 2-ntp2– bridge two metal centers resulting the formation of a paddle wheel dinuclear Cu2(CO2)4 SBU along with the formation of another Cu4(CO2)8 SBU (Figure S9). The 2D sheets are pillared by 4-bpdb ligands to form the 3D framework with a 1D channel along the b-axis containing the guest water molecules (c). Although the length of the N,N′-donor linker is higher in 2, the dimension of the channel is about 6.1 × 3.8 Å2 which is slightly smaller due to the bent nature of the 4-bpdb (Figure S11a). Moreover, the nitro groups are not directed toward the channel but rather the solvent accessible void estimated by PLATON is 710.7 Å3 which is 28.5% of the total crystal volume of 2491.5 Å3. Structural analysis with TOPOS suggests that the overall framework of 2 exhibits a 3,5-c binodal (d) net with stoichiometry (3-c)­(5-c) and the corresponding Schläfli symbol is {4.64.83.102}­{4.82}.
elements.clean_text: Block shaped greenish crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained at room temperature by the slow diffusion technique of aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2 and the disodium salt of 2-nitroterephthalic acid, [Na2(2-ntp)], with the methanolic solution of 4,4'-azobispyridine (azbpy) and N,N'-bispyridin-4-ylmethylenehydrazine (4-bpdb) linkers for 1 and 2, respectively. Compound 1 exhibits a 3D structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cu(II) ion, one azbpy linker, one 2-ntp2-, and one disorder lattice water molecule split into three fragments with 0.25, 0.25, and 0.5 individual occupancy. The five-coordinated Cu(II) center with CuO3N2 coordination environment is connected by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O3 a , and O4 b ) from three 2-ntp2- and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4 c ) of two different azbpy linkers (a) exhibiting a distorted trigonal bipyramidal structure. Here each 2-ntp2- ligand bridges with three Cu(II) centers in a bridging monodentate-bidentate fashion and exhibits a 2D sheet of [Cu(2-ntp)] n  in the crystallographic ab plane (b) through the formation of Cu3(CO2)5 trinuclear secondary building units (SBUs) (Figure S8). The 2D sheets are further connected by an azbpy ligand to form a 3D framework with water filled 1D channel along b-axis (c) with the channel dimensions of about 6.5 × 3.0 Å2 (Figure S10a). Interestingly, the nitro groups are embedded in the pore wall of the said channel, and even in the presence of bulky nitro groups, the total solvent accessible void without the lattice water molecule is pretty high, 773.5 Å3 estimated by PLATON, which is 32.7% of the total crystal volume of 2362.18 Å3. Structural analysis with TOPOS suggests that the overall framework of 1 exhibits a 3,5-c binodal net (d) with stoichiometry (3-c)(5-c) and the corresponding Schläfli symbol is {63}{69.8}. Compound 2 shows a 3D paddle-wheel structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cu(II) ion, one 4-bpdb linker, one 2-ntp2-, and two lattice water molecules. The Cu(II) center is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2 a , and O3 b ) from three different 2-ntp2- and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4 c ) from two different 4-bpdb linkers (a) and exhibits a distorted trigonal bipyramidal structure. Here each 2-ntp2- ligand bridges with three Cu(II) centers like 1 to form a 2D sheet of [Cu(2-ntp)] n  in the bc plane (b), but the bonding of the 2-ntp2- ligand is only slightly different than that of 1. In 2 the bidentate carboxylate groups of two different 2-ntp2- bridge two metal centers resulting the formation of a paddle wheel dinuclear Cu2(CO2)4 SBU along with the formation of another Cu4(CO2)8 SBU (Figure S9). The 2D sheets are pillared by 4-bpdb ligands to form the 3D framework with a 1D channel along the b-axis containing the guest water molecules (c). Although the length of the N,N'-donor linker is higher in 2, the dimension of the channel is about 6.1 × 3.8 Å2 which is slightly smaller due to the bent nature of the 4-bpdb (Figure S11a). Moreover, the nitro groups are not directed toward the channel but rather the solvent accessible void estimated by PLATON is 710.7 Å3 which is 28.5% of the total crystal volume of 2491.5 Å3. Structural analysis with TOPOS suggests that the overall framework of 2 exhibits a 3,5-c binodal (d) net with stoichiometry (3-c)(5-c) and the corresponding Schläfli symbol is {4.64.83.102}{4.82}.

(c) View of the 3D structure of 1 pillared by the azbpy ligand with 1D water channel. (d) Simplified topological representation of the 3,5-connected binodal 3D net in 1.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 and 2 and the dehydrated species of 1 (1a) has been carried out in the temperature range 30–600 °C and the as-synthesized PXRD patterns of both 1 and 2 (Figures S6 and S7) confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials with the simulated pattern. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of ∼3.55% around 75 °C corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calc. wt % 3.79; Figure S4); and the dehydrated framework is stable up to ∼285 °C without any further weight loss, but dehydrated 1a exhibits no weight loss up to 270 °C (Figure S4) indicating the absence of the guest water molecule which is lost during the dehydration process; after that, the dehydrated framework collapses into unidentified products by further heating. The PXRD pattern of dehydrated framework 1a, which is obtained by heating 1 at 150 °C under reduced pressure (Figure S6), shows an almost identical peak position to the as synthesized 1 which indicates the rigidity of the framework after the removal of the water molecule. The PXRD pattern of the rehydrated framework 1b (Figure S6) also exhibits the identical peak positions to the as-synthesized 1 after exposing the dehydrated 1a in water vapor for 7 days, indicating the reversible robustness of the framework of 1. The retention of the single crystallinity of 1 at high temperature encouraged us to do the corresponding crystal structure after removing the guest volatile from the parent framework through evacuation at 150 °C. Herein the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) reversibility study of 1 (deep green) has been performed which represents the dehydrated 1a (dark green) and rehydrated 1b structures with almost analogous cell parameters (Tables S3 and S4, ) showing the complete reversibility of the framework. It is not necessary to mention that the types of crystal systems and space groups in all three structures (1, 1a, and 1b) are equivalent, whereas the bond lengths and angles are almost equal with minor differences (Tables S2–S4). In TGA, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ∼7.13% at ∼85 °C corroborating the loss of two lattice water molecules (calc. wt % 6.95; Figure S5) and the dehydrated framework which is further stable up to ∼235 °C. The PXRD patterns (Figure S7) of dehydrated 2 (activated at 130 °C) are identical with those of the as-synthesized 2, indicating the rigidity of the framework after the removal of guest volatiles; however, unlike 1 the single crystallinity of 2 does not exist at high temperature.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 and 2 and the dehydrated species of 1 (1a) has been carried out in the temperature range 30-600 °C and the as-synthesized PXRD patterns of both 1 and 2 (Figures S6 and S7) confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials with the simulated pattern. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of ~3.55% around 75 °C corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calc. wt % 3.79; Figure S4); and the dehydrated framework is stable up to ~285 °C without any further weight loss, but dehydrated 1a exhibits no weight loss up to 270 °C (Figure S4) indicating the absence of the guest water molecule which is lost during the dehydration process; after that, the dehydrated framework collapses into unidentified products by further heating. The PXRD pattern of dehydrated framework 1a, which is obtained by heating 1 at 150 °C under reduced pressure (Figure S6), shows an almost identical peak position to the as synthesized 1 which indicates the rigidity of the framework after the removal of the water molecule. The PXRD pattern of the rehydrated framework 1b (Figure S6) also exhibits the identical peak positions to the as-synthesized 1 after exposing the dehydrated 1a in water vapor for 7 days, indicating the reversible robustness of the framework of 1. The retention of the single crystallinity of 1 at high temperature encouraged us to do the corresponding crystal structure after removing the guest volatile from the parent framework through evacuation at 150 °C. Herein the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) reversibility study of 1 (deep green) has been performed which represents the dehydrated 1a (dark green) and rehydrated 1b structures with almost analogous cell parameters (Tables S3 and S4, ) showing the complete reversibility of the framework. It is not necessary to mention that the types of crystal systems and space groups in all three structures (1, 1a, and 1b) are equivalent, whereas the bond lengths and angles are almost equal with minor differences (Tables S2-S4). In TGA, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ~7.13% at ~85 °C corroborating the loss of two lattice water molecules (calc. wt % 6.95; Figure S5) and the dehydrated framework which is further stable up to ~235 °C. The PXRD patterns (Figure S7) of dehydrated 2 (activated at 130 °C) are identical with those of the as-synthesized 2, indicating the rigidity of the framework after the removal of guest volatiles; however, unlike 1 the single crystallinity of 2 does not exist at high temperature.

1, 1a, and 1b are parent, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of 1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic Representation of the Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal (SC-SC) Reversibility of 1       a  1, 1a, and 1b are parent, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of 1, respectively.

elements.content:
1, 1a, and 1b are parent, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of 1, respectively.

Considering the stability of the framework confirmed by TGA and PXRD with appreciably large solvent accessible voids in the dehydrated frameworks of both 1 and 2, different gases (N2 at 77 and 298 K; H2 at 77 K; CH4 at 298 K; and CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K) as well as vapor sorption (H2O and EtOH at 298 K) have been investigated. Both compounds show selective CO2 adsorption () over other gases. This moderately high selective CO2 adsorption is quite logical due to the presence of highly polar −NO2 groups with the polarization of significantly negative charge density on O atoms which may interact with the Lewis acidic C center of CO2 molecules on the basis of the dipole–quadruple interaction. In addition, the N-based Lewis basic functional polar surfaces (−NN– and – CHNNCH−) in the framework may also act additively for the high CO2 selectivity. The space filling models of the dehydrated framework of 1 show a unidirectional channel along the b-axis (Figure S10) which attributes its lack of porosity toward N2 to the blocking of the 1D channel through diffusion of N2 molecules. It also shows a very low uptake at the surface for H2 at 77 K and CH4 at 298 K. It is evident in that 1 exhibits type I profile in CO2 adsorption at 195 K with a high uptake of CO2. Interestingly, it shows a remarkable step rise up to ∼134 cc/g in a very low pressure region (from 0.001 to 0.16 bar); after that, very slow uptake of CO2 was observed with the increase of pressure, which finally reaches ∼185 cc/g at 1 bar. It also shows reversible CO2 desorption along with an adsorption isotherm with a small hysteresis which probably originates from the adsorbent and adsorbate interaction. At the beginning, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of 1 is ∼44 kJ/mol obtained from adsorption data of CO2 (Figures S12 and S13) at two different temperatures (i.e., 273 and 298 K) using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation which is (d lnp/dT) = Q st/RT 2. After that, the isosteric heat of adsorption of 1 decreases with the uploading of adsorbate signifying the filling of their maximum affinity sites. The high Q st value of CO2 adsorption for 1 indicates strong interaction between NO2···CO2; NN···CO2; aromatic π···CO2; and cooperative CO2···CO2 interactions operating together or in an individual manner. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows appreciable uptake of CO2 at room temperature/273 K, which are 34 cc/g and 44 cc/g, respectively (Figure S12). Similar to 1, the dehydrated framework of 2 also shows no porosity toward N2 molecules with a similar reason for the presence of unidirectional channels along the b-axis (Figure S11) and the H2 uptake and CH4 adsorption are also negligible as that of 1. However, the CO2 adsorption isotherm shows interesting type V profile with good selectivity () over all the other gases mentioned earlier. In the CO2 adsorption profile of 2, it is observed that up to P = 0.55 bar, almost no adsorption has occurred, but after this pressure, there is a sharp uptake of CO2 observed which reaches 103 cc/g at P = 0.85 bar and then gradually attains the final value of 126 cc/g at P = 0.99 bar. After that, the reversible desorption profile with a large hysteresis is regenerated with an incomplete desorption which may be due to strong adsorbate–adsorbent interaction in 2. The gate-opening behaviorof 2 at P = 0.55 bar may be attributed to the expansion of the framework owing to the flexible nature of the pore which is constructed by a flexible ligand, 4-bpdb. The dehydrated 2 also shows nice CO2 uptake at room temperature and 273 K up to 10 cc/g and 15 cc/g, respectively (Figure S14). At the onset, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of 2 has been calculated like 1, taking two different CO2 adsorption measurements at 273 and 298 K (Figures S14 and S15) and found similarly with a high value (∼43 kJ/mol) as that of 1 due to similar reasons discussed above.

a  1, 1a, and 1b are parent, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of 1, respectively.  

Considering the stability of the framework confirmed by TGA and PXRD with appreciably large solvent accessible voids in the dehydrated frameworks of both 1 and 2, different gases (N2 at 77 and 298 K; H2 at 77 K; CH4 at 298 K; and CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K) as well as vapor sorption (H2O and EtOH at 298 K) have been investigated. Both compounds show selective CO2 adsorption () over other gases. This moderately high selective CO2 adsorption is quite logical due to the presence of highly polar -NO2 groups with the polarization of significantly negative charge density on O atoms which may interact with the Lewis acidic C center of CO2 molecules on the basis of the dipole-quadruple interaction. In addition, the N-based Lewis basic functional polar surfaces (-NN- and - CHNNCH-) in the framework may also act additively for the high CO2 selectivity. The space filling models of the dehydrated framework of 1 show a unidirectional channel along the b-axis (Figure S10) which attributes its lack of porosity toward N2 to the blocking of the 1D channel through diffusion of N2 molecules. It also shows a very low uptake at the surface for H2 at 77 K and CH4 at 298 K. It is evident in  that 1 exhibits type I profile in CO2 adsorption at 195 K with a high uptake of CO2. Interestingly, it shows a remarkable step rise up to ~134 cc/g in a very low pressure region (from 0.001 to 0.16 bar); after that, very slow uptake of CO2 was observed with the increase of pressure, which finally reaches ~185 cc/g at 1 bar. It also shows reversible CO2 desorption along with an adsorption isotherm with a small hysteresis which probably  originates from the adsorbent and adsorbate interaction. At the beginning, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of 1 is ~44 kJ/mol obtained from adsorption data of CO2 (Figures S12 and S13) at two different temperatures (i.e., 273 and 298 K) using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation which is (d lnp/dT) = Q st/RT 2. After that, the isosteric heat of adsorption of 1 decreases with the uploading of adsorbate signifying the filling of their maximum affinity sites. The high Q st value of CO2 adsorption for 1 indicates strong interaction between NO2⋅⋅⋅CO2; NN⋅⋅⋅CO2; aromatic π⋅⋅⋅CO2; and cooperative CO2⋅⋅⋅CO2 interactions operating together or in an individual manner. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows appreciable uptake of CO2 at room temperature/273 K, which are 34 cc/g and 44 cc/g, respectively (Figure S12). Similar to 1, the dehydrated framework of 2 also shows no porosity toward N2 molecules with a similar reason for the presence of unidirectional channels along the b-axis (Figure S11) and the H2 uptake and CH4 adsorption are also negligible as that of 1. However, the CO2 adsorption isotherm shows interesting type V profile with good selectivity () over all the other gases mentioned earlier. In the CO2 adsorption profile of 2, it is observed that up to P = 0.55 bar, almost no adsorption has occurred, but after this pressure, there is a sharp uptake of CO2 observed which reaches 103 cc/g at P = 0.85 bar and then gradually attains the final value of 126 cc/g at P = 0.99 bar. After that, the reversible desorption profile with a large hysteresis is regenerated with an incomplete desorption which may be due to strong adsorbate-adsorbent interaction in 2. The gate-opening behaviorof 2 at P = 0.55 bar may be attributed to the expansion of the framework owing to the flexible nature of the pore which is constructed by a flexible ligand, 4-bpdb. The dehydrated 2 also shows nice CO2 uptake at room temperature and 273 K up to 10 cc/g and 15 cc/g, respectively (Figure S14). At the onset, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of 2 has been calculated like 1, taking two different CO2 adsorption measurements at 273 and 298 K (Figures S14 and S15) and found similarly with a high value (~43 kJ/mol) as that of 1 due to similar reasons discussed above.

elements.content: Different gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 (CO2 at 195 K; N2 at 77 K; H2 at 77 K; and CH4 at 298 K). Filled symbols indicate adsorption and the open symbols show desorption curve.
elements.clean_text: 3  Different gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 (CO2 at 195 K; N2 at 77 K; H2 at 77 K; and CH4 at 298 K). Filled symbols indicate adsorption and the open symbols show desorption curve.

elements.content: To investigate the CO2 selectivity of both compounds 1 and 2 over N2 and CH4, the single component gas sorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and CH4 have also been measured at room temperature, i.e., at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (Figures S16 and S17). The uptake of CO2 over N2 and CH4 for both compounds at room temperature is found to be comparable, or even higher from the previously reported similar kinds of MOFs. For selectivity measurements, the initial slopes of the adsorption isotherms were calculated individually, and the ratios of the initial slopes of respective isotherms were used to estimate the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 and CH4 for both compounds based on initial slope calculation. Based on that, the CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivities for 1 are 13.5 and 2.3, while for 2, they are 15 and 5, respectively (Figures S18 and S19).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the CO2 selectivity of both compounds 1 and 2 over N2 and CH4, the single component gas sorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and CH4 have also been measured at room temperature, i.e., at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (Figures S16 and S17). The uptake of CO2 over N2 and CH4 for both compounds at room temperature is found to be comparable, or even higher from the previously reported similar kinds of MOFs. For selectivity measurements, the initial slopes of the adsorption isotherms were calculated individually, and the ratios of the initial slopes of respective isotherms were used to estimate the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 and CH4 for both compounds based on initial slope calculation. Based on that, the CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivities for 1 are 13.5 and 2.3, while for 2, they are 15 and 5, respectively (Figures S18 and S19).

elements.content: We have also measured the solvent sorption isotherms of two polar solvents, H2O and EtOH, at 298 K for both compounds, to observe the solvent–framework interaction. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows a lower uptake up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.35, and after that an almost steep uptake up to a volume of ∼126 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.95 (Figure S20). The said volume indicates the uptake of 2.5 water molecules per formula unit, which is much greater than the calculated value (1.0 water per formula unit), observed possibly due to the expansion of the layered structure which occurs in the higher pressure region. The EtOH vapor sorption of 1 gives a simple type I adsorption profile with saturation value of ∼107 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9 (Figure S20). On the other hand, for dehydrated 2, the H2O and EtOH vapor sorption isotherms at 298 K (Figure S21) show nearly the same pattern and comparatively greater hysteresis as that of 1 with final uptake of EtOH vapor of 44 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.89 and water vapor 75 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9 corresponding to 1.6 water molecules per formula unit, which closely supports the value obtained in TGA study of 2. In both H2O and EtOH adsorption–desorption curves of 1 and 2, hysteresis is observed which is due to the strong adsorbent–adsorbate interaction.
elements.clean_text: We have also measured the solvent sorption isotherms of two polar solvents, H2O and EtOH, at 298 K for both compounds, to observe the solvent-framework interaction. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows a lower uptake up to P/P 0 ~ 0.35, and after that an almost steep uptake up to a volume of ~126 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.95 (Figure S20). The said volume indicates the uptake of 2.5 water molecules per formula unit, which is much greater than the calculated value (1.0 water per formula unit), observed possibly due to the expansion of the layered structure which occurs in the higher pressure region. The EtOH vapor sorption of 1 gives a simple type I adsorption profile with saturation value of ~107 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.9 (Figure S20). On the other hand, for dehydrated 2, the H2O and EtOH vapor sorption isotherms at 298 K (Figure S21) show nearly the same pattern and comparatively greater hysteresis as that of 1 with final uptake of EtOH vapor of 44 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.89 and water vapor 75 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.9 corresponding to 1.6 water molecules per formula unit, which closely supports the value obtained in TGA study of 2. In both H2O and EtOH adsorption-desorption curves of 1 and 2, hysteresis is observed which is due to the strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction.

elements.content: It has been noted in previous reports that the −NH2 and −OH functionalized MOFs significantly enhance CO2 adsorption selectively over the others, due to Lewis acid–base type interactions as well as H-bonding interactions between the polar −NH2 and −OH groups and the Lewis acidic quadrupolar CO2 molecule. However, the prospect of −NO2 functionalized MOFs had not been explored for CO2 adsorption due to the unsatisfactory results with such MOFs, in terms of amount of CO2 uptake as well as the selectively. However, here we have synthesized two robust MOFs which show extremely enhanced CO2 uptake with remarkable selectivity which clearly established the utility of −NO2 functionalized MOFs for selective CO2 uptake rather than nonfunctionalized or other polar functionalized MOFs containing −NH2 or −OH groups in the pore wall. The high Q st value for CO2 for both compounds evidently supports the strong adsorbent–adsorbate interactions, which strongly correlates the interaction of O atoms of the nitro group with the quadruple moment of the CO2 mentioned earlier. It is clear from the above discussion that if the projection of bulky −NO2 groups is not blocking the void of the framework, it can be equally capable or sometimes more efficient to produce MOFs with CO2 capture selectivity. In conclusion, this work will add some new thoughts on the traditional protocol of synthesizing MOFs with CO2 selectivity.
elements.clean_text: It has been noted in previous reports that the -NH2 and -OH functionalized MOFs significantly enhance CO2 adsorption selectively over the others, due to Lewis acid-base type interactions as well as H-bonding interactions between the polar -NH2 and -OH groups and the Lewis acidic quadrupolar CO2 molecule. However, the prospect of -NO2 functionalized MOFs had not been explored for CO2 adsorption due to the unsatisfactory results with such MOFs, in terms of amount of CO2 uptake as well as the selectively. However, here we have synthesized two robust MOFs which show extremely enhanced CO2 uptake with remarkable selectivity which clearly established the utility of -NO2 functionalized MOFs for selective CO2 uptake rather than nonfunctionalized or other polar functionalized MOFs containing -NH2 or -OH groups in the pore wall. The high Q st value for CO2 for both compounds evidently supports the strong adsorbent-adsorbate interactions, which strongly correlates the interaction of O atoms of the nitro group with the quadruple moment of the CO2 mentioned earlier. It is clear from the above discussion that if the projection of bulky -NO2 groups is not blocking the void of the framework, it can be equally capable or sometimes more efficient to produce MOFs with CO2 capture selectivity. In conclusion, this work will add some new thoughts on the traditional protocol of synthesizing MOFs with CO2 selectivity.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 and 2 and the dehydrated species of 1 (1a) has been carried out in the temperature range 30–600 °C and the as-synthesized PXRD patterns of both 1 and 2 (Figures S6 and S7) confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials with the simulated pattern. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of ∼3.55% around 75 °C corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calc. wt % 3.79; Figure S4); and the dehydrated framework is stable up to ∼285 °C without any further weight loss, but dehydrated 1a exhibits no weight loss up to 270 °C (Figure S4) indicating the absence of the guest water molecule which is lost during the dehydration process; after that, the dehydrated framework collapses into unidentified products by further heating. The PXRD pattern of dehydrated framework 1a, which is obtained by heating 1 at 150 °C under reduced pressure (Figure S6), shows an almost identical peak position to the as synthesized 1 which indicates the rigidity of the framework after the removal of the water molecule. The PXRD pattern of the rehydrated framework 1b (Figure S6) also exhibits the identical peak positions to the as-synthesized 1 after exposing the dehydrated 1a in water vapor for 7 days, indicating the reversible robustness of the framework of 1. The retention of the single crystallinity of 1 at high temperature encouraged us to do the corresponding crystal structure after removing the guest volatile from the parent framework through evacuation at 150 °C. Herein the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) reversibility study of 1 (deep green) has been performed which represents the dehydrated 1a (dark green) and rehydrated 1b structures with almost analogous cell parameters (Tables S3 and S4, ) showing the complete reversibility of the framework. It is not necessary to mention that the types of crystal systems and space groups in all three structures (1, 1a, and 1b) are equivalent, whereas the bond lengths and angles are almost equal with minor differences (Tables S2–S4). In TGA, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ∼7.13% at ∼85 °C corroborating the loss of two lattice water molecules (calc. wt % 6.95; Figure S5) and the dehydrated framework which is further stable up to ∼235 °C. The PXRD patterns (Figure S7) of dehydrated 2 (activated at 130 °C) are identical with those of the as-synthesized 2, indicating the rigidity of the framework after the removal of guest volatiles; however, unlike 1 the single crystallinity of 2 does not exist at high temperature.

We have also measured the solvent sorption isotherms of two polar solvents, H2O and EtOH, at 298 K for both compounds, to observe the solvent–framework interaction. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows a lower uptake up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.35, and after that an almost steep uptake up to a volume of ∼126 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.95 (Figure S20). The said volume indicates the uptake of 2.5 water molecules per formula unit, which is much greater than the calculated value (1.0 water per formula unit), observed possibly due to the expansion of the layered structure which occurs in the higher pressure region. The EtOH vapor sorption of 1 gives a simple type I adsorption profile with saturation value of ∼107 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9 (Figure S20). On the other hand, for dehydrated 2, the H2O and EtOH vapor sorption isotherms at 298 K (Figure S21) show nearly the same pattern and comparatively greater hysteresis as that of 1 with final uptake of EtOH vapor of 44 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.89 and water vapor 75 cc/g at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9 corresponding to 1.6 water molecules per formula unit, which closely supports the value obtained in TGA study of 2. In both H2O and EtOH adsorption–desorption curves of 1 and 2, hysteresis is observed which is due to the strong adsorbent–adsorbate interaction.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 and 2 and the dehydrated species of 1 (1a) has been carried out in the temperature range 30-600 °C and the as-synthesized PXRD patterns of both 1 and 2 (Figures S6 and S7) confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials with the simulated pattern. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of ~3.55% around 75 °C corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calc. wt % 3.79; Figure S4); and the dehydrated framework is stable up to ~285 °C without any further weight loss, but dehydrated 1a exhibits no weight loss up to 270 °C (Figure S4) indicating the absence of the guest water molecule which is lost during the dehydration process; after that, the dehydrated framework collapses into unidentified products by further heating. The PXRD pattern of dehydrated framework 1a, which is obtained by heating 1 at 150 °C under reduced pressure (Figure S6), shows an almost identical peak position to the as synthesized 1 which indicates the rigidity of the framework after the removal of the water molecule. The PXRD pattern of the rehydrated framework 1b (Figure S6) also exhibits the identical peak positions to the as-synthesized 1 after exposing the dehydrated 1a in water vapor for 7 days, indicating the reversible robustness of the framework of 1. The retention of the single crystallinity of 1 at high temperature encouraged us to do the corresponding crystal structure after removing the guest volatile from the parent framework through evacuation at 150 °C. Herein the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) reversibility study of 1 (deep green) has been performed which represents the dehydrated 1a (dark green) and rehydrated 1b structures with almost analogous cell parameters (Tables S3 and S4, ) showing the complete reversibility of the framework. It is not necessary to mention that the types of crystal systems and space groups in all three structures (1, 1a, and 1b) are equivalent, whereas the bond lengths and angles are almost equal with minor differences (Tables S2-S4). In TGA, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ~7.13% at ~85 °C corroborating the loss of two lattice water molecules (calc. wt % 6.95; Figure S5) and the dehydrated framework which is further stable up to ~235 °C. The PXRD patterns (Figure S7) of dehydrated 2 (activated at 130 °C) are identical with those of the as-synthesized 2, indicating the rigidity of the framework after the removal of guest volatiles; however, unlike 1 the single crystallinity of 2 does not exist at high temperature.

We have also measured the solvent sorption isotherms of two polar solvents, H2O and EtOH, at 298 K for both compounds, to observe the solvent-framework interaction. The dehydrated framework of 1 shows a lower uptake up to P/P 0 ~ 0.35, and after that an almost steep uptake up to a volume of ~126 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.95 (Figure S20). The said volume indicates the uptake of 2.5 water molecules per formula unit, which is much greater than the calculated value (1.0 water per formula unit), observed possibly due to the expansion of the layered structure which occurs in the higher pressure region. The EtOH vapor sorption of 1 gives a simple type I adsorption profile with saturation value of ~107 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.9 (Figure S20). On the other hand, for dehydrated 2, the H2O and EtOH vapor sorption isotherms at 298 K (Figure S21) show nearly the same pattern and comparatively greater hysteresis as that of 1 with final uptake of EtOH vapor of 44 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.89 and water vapor 75 cc/g at P/P 0 ~ 0.9 corresponding to 1.6 water molecules per formula unit, which closely supports the value obtained in TGA study of 2. In both H2O and EtOH adsorption-desorption curves of 1 and 2, hysteresis is observed which is due to the strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Role of -NO2 and -NH2 Groups in CO2 Adsorption

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment around penta-coordinated Cu­(II) with atom labeling scheme in 1 (azbpy ligand has been omitted for clarity): Cu (green), O (red), N (blue), and C (black). (b) 2D arrangement in 1 constructed by both metal and 2-nitroterephthalate moiety (azbpy has been omitted for clarity). (c) View of the 3D structure of 1 pillared by the azbpy ligand with 1D water channel. (d) Simplified topological representation of the 3,5-connected binodal 3D net in 1.

metadata.title:
Selective CO2 Adsorption by Nitro Functionalized
Metal Organic Frameworks
